msDesc.head: Collection of medical, astrological, and theological works

summary.seg: This two-volume manuscript is a composite of seven parts, whose production ranges in date from the late twelfth to the fifteenth centuries. It is possible, though, that Part 3 (ff. 67r-74v) and Part 4 (ff. 75r-189v) originally belonged together: they may both have been copied by the same scribe, but there are disparities in their layout and decoration that suggest different points of origin.

The manuscript contains a large collection of medical, theological, and astrological works in Latin and Middle English, such as The Cloud of Unknowing, a Middle English guide to contemplative prayer that dates to the second half of the fourteenth century. Overall, the book lacks any illumination or illustration, however there is fragmentary evidence to show that some had previously been present: during the cataloguing of the manuscript, the remains of an astrological miniature of the Zodiac sign Cancer have been identified on a fragmentary leaf in Part 7 (f. [242a]).

Dr Clarck Drieshen
Project Cataloguer
Cambridge University Library

foliation.note: Numbering (Roman numerals) in brown ink at the centre of the upper margin, the upper half of the outer margin, or the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.

The medieval foliator has not included f. 5 and f. 66; and has erroneously jumped from 'lix' (f. 63) to 'lxx' (f. 64), which is then erroneously continued. A modern hand has corrected the last two folios to 'lx' (f. 64) and 'lxi' (f. 65) in pencil and added foliation to f. 66 ('lxij') as well.
Foliation sequence not followed in this description.
A sequence of partial foliation written on every tenth leaf in Volume 1 and intermittently in Volume 2, in pencil, in the lower right-hand corner of the recto side of the leaf.
Foliation sequence not followed in this description.

Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos, in part by Henry BradshawBradshaw, Henry, 1831-1886, University Librarian 1867-1886, who subdivided the manuscript's numbering into separate volumes, prefaced by a opening bracket (see f. 75r for an example = (2 . As per the historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library that Bradshaw established, folio numbers were assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (but since this foliation sequence is not followed in this description, these folio numbers are not recorded here).

Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos. The start of this sequence (ff. 1r-67r follows that written by an unidentified 20th-century hand. From 68r onwards, the foliation continues in sequence (ignoring the sub-divisions in the earlier foliation of the manuscript) throughout both volumes. This was written by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..
A stub with a fragment of an astrological text has been assigned the folio designation f. [242a] in order to provide a reference for the mutilated leaf without disrupting this foliation sequence.
Folio numbers ff. 110 and 111 assigned to leaves no longer present in the volume (as per historic foliation practice at Cambridge University Library).
This foliation sequence is followed in this description.

collation.formula: four leaves | 1-414 56 | 68 | 78 88-6 (3rd-8th leaves missing) 98-7 (1st-7th leaves missing) 10-128 138-2 (1st and 2nd leaves missing) 14-228 | 238 24-2510 | 268-1 (1st leaf missing) 27-288 | eight leaves

additions.p: Notes on missing leaves and parts in the manuscript written in pencil in upper margins.
Quire signatures (in the form of lower-case letters) written in pencil in the lower right-hand corner on the recto side of the first leaf of each quire, perhaps by H.L. PinkPink, H. L..

binding.p: Black quarter leather binding with green sides.
Binding height: 135mm (vols 1 and 2); width: 95mm (vols 1 and 2); depth: 30mm (vols 1 and 2).
Bound by Gray in Cambridge in 1953.

provenance.p: Thomas Ball (fl. late 16th or early 17th century) Ball, Thomas, fl. late 16th or early 17th century : his name inscribed on the lower margins of ff. 53v-54r (written upside down): 'Th. Ball'; and also on ff. 231v-232r: 231v-232r: 'Ball me (?) sanum'; perhaps Thomas Ball (1590-1659), of Emmanuel College Cambridge, and vicar of All Saints Northampton.
John Moore (1646-1714), bishop of Ely Moore, John, 1646-1714 : no. 126 (f. 1r) in Bernard, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum AngliÃ¦ et HiberniÃ¦ (c. 1697).

history.acquisition: Presented to the University Library in 1715 by George I George I, King of Great Britain, 1660-1727 : but without the donation bookplate engraved by John Pine Pine, John, 1690-1756 in 1736

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on Margaret Connolly, Manuscripts in the University Library, Cambridge (Dd-Oo) , The Index of Middle English Prose, 17 (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009) and an unpublished description of the manuscript composed between 1926 and 1930 by M.R. James James, M.R. (Montague Rhodes), 1862-1936, now held in the University Archives (UA ULIB 7/3/74).

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.6.39, ff. 1r-4v

msItem.title: Lecture notes
msItem.note: Almost illegible, but probably related to philosophy, logic, or mathematics.

collation.p: Four leaves from another manuscript that have been reused as flyleaves for this manuscript.

supportDesc.condition: Glue stains on f. 1r suggest that the leaf is a former pastedown.

p.seg: No ruling. About 35 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Written by a single hand in an extremely cursive hand.

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 14th century or 15th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.6.39, ff. 5r-66v

msItem.title: Practica breuis
msItem.author: Joannes Platearius
msItem.incipit: 5r Amicum induit
msItem.explicit: 65r puluis inde factus fistule in[...]atur

msItem.title: Panormia seu Liber derivationum
msItem.author: Osbern of Gloucester
msItem.incipit: 65r Si rogat addideris con- congregat e- dat in infert / Pre superat sub substituit pro protrahit inter / Querit de minuit ab destruit arque superbit
msItem.note: Full transcription, save for an additional last line which has not been transcribed.

msItem.title: Medical recipes
msItem.note: Two medical recipes, followed by an unread instruction that involves reading the Pater noster.

msItem.title: Recipes for medical oils
msItem.note: A marginal inscription reads: oleis fratris et sicut.

msItem.title: Definitions of terms in medical works by Hippocrates
msItem.author: Hippocrates
msItem.incipit: 66r In periodis inparibus [sic: imparibus]
msItem.explicit: 66v variole id est pocke [morbilli]
msItem.note: The text appears to refer to works by Hippocrates: 'Explicit liber Afforisimorum', 'pro[g]nosticon'.

msItem.title: Charm
msItem.incipit: 66v le flum iordan cent humes ha
msItem.note: Possibly a blood-staunching charm, using the motif of Christ's baptism in the River Jordan: Le flum Jordan.
Written twice in different hands: added in the late 13th or early 14th century.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink in the lower right-hand corners of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: Large ink or water stains on ff. 5-9 and ff. 64v-65r, rendering sections of the text illegible.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, with occasional line ruling. Mainly single columns (except ff. 66r-66r, which has three columns, and 66v-66v, which has two). 26 lines to the page, written above top line.

handNote.p: Written by a hand in a script with features of protogothic and Northern Textualis.

decoNote.p: Large (2-4 lines) initials in red or green, often with minor penwork decoration and pen-flourishing in the opposite colour.
Headers higlighted in red ink.
Regular (1 line) capitals higlighted in red ink.
Paraphs in red ink.

note.p: A possible title inscription for this part of the manuscript: liber medicinale added to f. 66v in a (?) 14th-century hand.

provenance.p: John Claftun (fl. 13th century) Claftun, John, fl. 13th century : his name inscribed on f. 66r: Magister iohannes claftun - Magister mei.
Peter Durant (fl. 15th century) Durant, Peter, fl. 15th century : his name inscribed on f. 66v: Petri durant.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 30 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe in an Anglicana script.

decoNote.p: Regular (1 line) capitals highlighted in red ink.
Paraphs in red ink.
Underlining in red ink.

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 14th or early 15th century.

msItem.title: The Cloud of Unknowing

msItem.incipit: 75r God unto wom alle hertes ben open and unto whom alle wille spekith and unto wom no priuey Ã¾ing is hid i beseche Ã¾e so for to clense Ã¾e entent of myn herte wiÃ¾ Ã¾e unspekable Èift of Ã¾i grace

msItem.author: Augustine

msItem.author: Richard of St Victor

msItem.title: Prayer to God [English translation of 'Concede mihi, misericors Deus']
msItem.author: Pseudo-Thomas Aquinas
msItem.incipit: 133r O Ã¾ou merciful lord god i besche Ã¾e graunt unto me whatsoeuere be plesinge unto Ã¾e feruently to desiren wiseli to seken and serchyn sothfastli for to knowen and parfiÈtli to compleschen and fulfillen only to Ã¾e preising and Ã¾e glorie of Ã¾i blissed name
msItem.explicit: 133v and graunt me alwei to endresse and directe myn hert to Ã¾e ward and in my trespassing
msItem.note: Incomplete; a complete copy of the text occurs on ff. 163v-165r. Only the latter copy attributes the prayer to Thomas Aquinas.
Unique according to Connolly (2009), but another version which attributes the translation to Princess Mary in 1527 occurs in London, British Libary, Add. MS 17012, ff. 192v-194r.

msItem.title: De domo conscientiae
msItem.author: Pseudo-Hugh of St Victor
msItem.incipit: 134r Domus hec in qua habitamus ex omni parte minatur ruinam
msItem.explicit: 157r pocius contemplacione quam terrestrium occupacione
msItem.finalRubric: 157r Explicit hugo de consciencia / Valeat in Christo et vigeat qui verum videat

msItem.title: The XVI Points of Charity
msItem.incipit: 157r Man among thi mirÃ¾e Ã¾is haue in mynde / Whennes Ã¾u cam and weder Ã¾u tendis
msItem.explicit: 157r I ham not worÃ¾ to gon as longe as me want par charite

msItem.title: De spirituali amicitia
msItem.author: Aelred of Rievaulx
msItem.incipit: 158r Est enim ait regressus ad amicum excepto conuicio et inproperio et superbia et mysterii reuelatione et plaga dolosa
msItem.explicit: 162r cum deus fuerit omnia in ominbus. Amen

msItem.title: Prayer to the Virgin Mary and St Anne
msItem.incipit: 162r Et benedicat sit mater tua anna que te virgo genuit / Et benedictus sit venter de quo caro tua virginea processit. Amen
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: De dignitate sacerdotum
msItem.author: Pseudo-Bernard of Clairvaux
msItem.incipit: 162v O Quantam dignitatem contulit vobis deus
msItem.explicit: 163v omnibus dico vigilitate etcaetea

msItem.title: Prayer to God [English translation of 'Concede mihi, misericors Deus']
msItem.author: Pseudo-Thomas Aquinas
msItem.incipit: 163v-164r O Ã¾ouÈ merciful lord god i besche Ã¾e graunt unto me whatoeuere be plesing unto Ã¾e feruently to desiren wysely for to seken and sergen sothfastli for to knowen and parfiÈtly to compleschen and fulfillen onli to Ã¾e preising and Ã¾e glorie of Ã¾i blissed name
msItem.explicit: 165r and be in possessioun of Ã¾i eternal blisse be continuÈaunce of gladnesse Ã¾at neuere schal haue ende amen
msItem.note: Complete; an incomplete version of the text occurs on ff. 133r-133v.
Unique according to Connolly (2009), but another version which attributes the translation to Princess Mary in 1527 occurs in London, British Libary, Add. MS 17012, ff. 192v-194r.

msItem.title: Liber de doctrina dicendi et tacendi
msItem.author: Albertano da Brescia
msItem.incipit: 166r Inicio et medio ac fine mei tractatus assit gratia sancti spiritus
msItem.explicit: 177r et eterna guadia nos faciat peruenire. Amen
msItem.finalRubric: 177r Explicit liber de doctrina dicendi et tacendi ab albertano causidico Brissiensi de hora sancte agathe compositus et compilatus

msItem.title: A Dialogue between Reason and Adversity
msItem.rubric: 177v A Dialogue between Reason and Adversity
msItem.incipit: 177v Nature was not my frende Ã¾at suffrede me to be bore of unsemeli schap resoun
msItem.explicit: 188v not only hard fare of mete and of drynk but also of oÃ¾er tribulaciones it schulde turne to swetnesse aduersite
msItem.note: Unique copy, but imperfect at the end; based on Petrarch's De remediis utriusque fortunae.

msItem.title: Prayer (unfinished)
msItem.incipit: 189r And for me in the nam of god an
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Prayers to God
msItem.incipit: 189v O lord of whome I doe depend behold my carful hert for when thy will and pleasur is relese I relese me of my smart / O God whatt frende hath for his frende abidden halfe such paine and wooe as thou my god and guide most Just hast dou for mee thy Cruell foe
msItem.note: Full transcription; added by two hands in the 16th century.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in decorative banderols in brown ink in the right-hand lower corners of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: Many of the decorated initials have been blurred or smudged.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only. Single columns. 26-33 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by different hands in an Anglicana script with Secretary influences (see the single-compartment 'a').

decoNote.p: Two large (5-6 lines) puzzle initial in blue and red in a frame of red and blue ink with floral motifs inside the letter and a partial (one-sided) border in red ink (ff. 75r, 79v).
Large (3 lines) blue initials in frames of red penwork decoration with pen-flourishing extending into the margins.
Line fillers in blue or/and red ink.
Paraphs in blue or red ink.

physDesc.additions: Prayers in English and Latin added in a 16th-century hand to the margins of ff. 119v, 123v, 126v, 127r, 179v.

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 14th or early 15th century.

provenance.p: Thomas [? Colman] (fl. c. 1475-1450) [? Colman], Thomas, fl. c. 1475-1450 : his name inscribed on f. 67r: 'sir thomas [?] collman]'.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.6.39, ff. 190r-217v

msItem.title: Scala Claustralium
msItem.author: Guigo II
msItem.incipit: 190r Cum die quadam corporali manuum labore occupatus et spiritualis hominis exercicia cogitare cepissem Quatuor spirituales gradus
msItem.explicit: 196r delicatus est sponsus est nobilis est
msItem.finalRubric: 196r Explicit scala claustralium que dicitur scala celi
msItem.note: Attributed to Adam the Carthusian ('Autore Adamo Carthusiensis') by Thomas Tanner (1674-1735) Tanner, Thomas, 1674-1735 in an inscription in the upper margin of f. 190r.

msItem.title: Prayer on the Passion
msItem.incipit: 196r Domine sancte pater eterne deus propter tuam largitatem et filii tui caritatem qui pro nobis sustinuit passionem
msItem.explicit: 196r nichil me afficiat nisi tu nichil me contristet nisi culpa. Amen

msItem.title: Sequence of prayers on the Passion and wounds of Christ
msItem.incipit: 196r Omnibus consideratis. paradisus voluptatis. es ihesu piisime
msItem.explicit: 197r Dum vidisti deum spretum ut me ducas ad hunc cetum quem Christus eripuit. Amen

msItem.title: Prayer on the Passion
msItem.incipit: 197r O crux frutex saluificus viuo fonte rigatus
msItem.explicit: 197v Ad parte fit mortalibus eterne vite status

listBibl.bibl: Mone, Hymni Latini Medii aevi, I, p. 150

msItem.title: Tractatus de duodecim utilitatibus tribulationis
msItem.author: Pseudo-Peter of Blois [here not attributed]
msItem.incipit: 198r Da nobis auxilium in tribulacione
msItem.explicit: 213v Per multas tribulaciones oportet nos introire in regnum celorum. Ad quod nos perducat qui sine fine viuit et regnat. Amen

msItem.title: Hymn to the Virgin Mary
msItem.incipit: 213v Sponsa Joseph dia genetrix lux virgo Maria
msItem.explicit: 214r valeat per tempora longa

msItem.title: A motto
msItem.incipit: 214v In domino confido Ryght reue[re]nt
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: 217r This indenture made the ffirst daye of meaye in ye ffyrst yeare of the Rayne of our souerayn Ladie Ellizabethe by the grace of god of England Fran[ce] and of Erlande
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the 16th century.

supportDesc.condition: Water stains throughout. Damage has rendered the last few lines on f. 218r. Some text has been lost due to damage to the inner margins of ff. 223-226: these have been repaired with blank paper.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, occasional line ruling. Single columns. 25 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe in a cursive script with Anglicana and Secretary features.

decoNote.p: Two-line initials in red ink.
Explicits with display capitals highlighted and either underlined in red ink or placed in a frame of red ink (ff. 196r, 213).
One-line capitals highlighted in red ink.
Paraphs in red ink.
Underlining in red ink.

origin.origDate: Copied in the late 14th or early 15th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.6.39, ff. 218r-240v

msItem.title: Contra Jovinianum
msItem.author: Jerome
msItem.incipit: 218r Satis habundeque christiane pudicicie et virginitatis angelice de divinis libris exempla prebuimus
msItem.explicit: 240r Roma aut fortitudinis nomen est iuxta grecos aut sullimitatis iuxta hebreos. Omnia vincit amor: et nos cedamus amori

msItem.title: Theological notes
msItem.note: Added in the late 13th or early 14th century.

supportDesc.condition: Water stains throughout. Damage has rendered the last few lines on f. 218r. Some text has been lost due to damage to the inner margins of ff. 223-226: these have been repaired with blank paper.

p.seg: Ruled in leadpoint, frame only, but only rarely visible: it is not possible to determine whether the text is written above or below the top line. Single columns. 23-25 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by a single scribe in a protogothic script.

decoNote.p: Large (2-6 lines) initials in green or red sometimes with Arabesque motifs in the same or opposite colours inside the letters.
Rubrics in red.
One-line capitals highlighted in red.
Run-over symbols (ff. 228r, 240r) highlighted in red.

origin.origDate: Copied in the second half of the 12th century.

msIdentifier.idno: Cambridge, University Library, MS Ii.6.39, ff. 241r-248v

msItem.title: Miracle of St Augustine of Canterbury at Compton
msItem.incipit: 241r In pago Oxorifordensi [sic]' est villa cummeton [sic: 'Cumpton'] nomine quo confessor beatus agustinus praedicasset
msItem.explicit: 241r relictis [...] beatum Augustinus omnibus diebus vite secutus diem clausit extremum et gaudium intravit eter[nae]
msItem.note: The incipit refers to Woodstock, Oxfordshire.

listBibl.bibl: Acta Sanctorum, 19 [May part 6] (1846), Appendix: Ex Chronico Joannis Bromtoni. De mortuis, ad evictionem Decimarum et Excommunicationis vim probandam, suscitatis.

msItem.title: Astronomical instructions
msItem.incipit: 241v Si vis scire qualiter hore diei cognoscuntur
msItem.explicit: 241v Si minus minue et patebat altitudo et co[...] et post f[...] sole non lucente
msItem.note: Five short tracts with instructions, the four latter ones beginning: 'Quadrantum in quadante'; 'Si igitur vis sicre in quo gradu altitudinis sit sol'; 'Si vis scire altitudinem aliter rei'; 'Si res erecta ut curris nec sit in plano'.

msItem.title: Exposition on the Gospel of John I
msItem.incipit: 242r In principio erat uerbum: Quia in tribus aliorum euangeliorum dictis modus humane natiuitatis Christi describitur
msItem.explicit: 242v aqua accepimus omnes et opus accipiemus in eterna beatitudine etcaetera

msItem.title: Fragment of an astrological text
msItem.note: The remaining text on f. [242a] recto reads 'Cancer' and a fragment of a miniature on f. [242a] verso shows a crab's claw with a star drawn inside it.

msItem.title: Sermon on the Gospel of Luke
msItem.incipit: 243r Cum audieritis praelia et cediciones
msItem.explicit: 243r cumque cepissent laudes canere uertit dominus insidias eorum in semet ipsos
msItem.note: The sermon draws from Gregory the Great's Homiliae in Evangelia.

msItem.title: Exempla
msItem.incipit: 243v ffilippus rex francie filius lodowici quondam nobilem
msItem.explicit: 243v sic que suspensus est ille diues
msItem.note: Collection of four exempla; followed by a faint (?) theological note in the lower margin by a different hand.

msItem.title: Aequivoca
msItem.author: Pseudo-John of Garland [here not attributed]
msItem.incipit: 244r Augustus ti.to. cesar uel mensis habeto
msItem.explicit: 244v est bubo uolucris . est morbus bubo sub ano apostema

msItem.title: Poem on council
msItem.incipit: 244v Femineis uerbis nec equo qui pascitur herbis
msItem.explicit: 244v e a solail apres nunne fet a crere Chival pu de regaine e a parole feminin
msItem.note: A Latin verse followed by a French translation, with the latter beginning: 'Chival pu de regaine e a parole feminine'.

msItem.title: Couplet
msItem.incipit: 244v Jo su rai e regne haut. si fu jo me pou me vaut / Jo fu riche or nai nent. ki fit io forte ma ioie vent
msItem.note: Full transcription.

msItem.title: Distichs on the Herods
msItem.incipit: 244v Ascalonita necat pueros . Antura iohannem / Agrippa Iacobum, claudens in carcere Petrum

listBibl.bibl: Walther, Initia carminum ac versuum medii aeui (1969), no. 13110

msItem.title: Gloss on Revelation XII
msItem.incipit: 245r signum magnum aparuit [sic] in celo
msItem.explicit: 245r set [...] stellarum

msItem.title: Note on the masses on Christmas Day
msItem.incipit: 245v Sacerdos in die natalis ter celebrat . prima missa statum ante legem significat
msItem.explicit: 245v post missa de die preces de Defunctis

msItem.title: Dial of Ahaz
msItem.incipit: 245v Sol qui per [...] .x. linearum in horologio etam tempore ezechie
msItem.explicit: 245v per .x. gradus in horologio retrorsum vnde excidant ad orcum iusticie reueritur

msItem.title: Sermon
msItem.incipit: 245v Rex est hodie et cras moritur
msItem.explicit: 248v in figura in cordibus uestris etcaetera

collation.p: This part consists of 8 (? separate) leaves.

p.seg: No ruling. Single frames. 25-38 lines to the page.

handNote.p: Copied by various hands in cursive scripts.

decoNote.p: One large black initial with red penwork decoration (f. 242r).
One large, two-line plain red initial (f. 244r).
Underlining in red ink.

change.persName: Dr Clarck Drieshen, Project Cataloguer in Curious Cures in Cambridge Libraries, Cambridge University Library
